misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that writing (y/n*z) is an unambiguous way to compute the road-trip cost and may not realize how left-to-right evaluation and precedence affect chained division/multiplication (or that explicit grouping is often needed to reflect the intended formula).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `*` and `/` have the same precedence and are evaluated left-to-right. While `y/n*z` does compute `(y/n)*z` (which is the correct formula here), students who don’t understand this rule can easily write expressions that work accidentally or fail when the intended formula differs (e.g., `y/(n*z)`). The underlying gap is an incomplete mental model of expression evaluation order and when parentheses are required to match a real-world formula.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: No error for the given problem/input; potential wrong numeric result in variants of the formula if the student’s intended grouping differs.
